concepts.title: Basic Syntax
bullets: List comprehensions create lists using a compact expression.
Basic form: [expression for item in iterable].
The expression transforms each item from the iterable.
Result is a new list containing all transformed values.
More readable than equivalent for-loop with append.
concepts.example_hint: Show a simple list comprehension that squares numbers.

concepts.title: Filtering with Conditions
bullets: Add an if clause to filter items: [expr for x in iter if cond].
Only items where the condition is True are included.
The condition is evaluated for each item in sequence.
Multiple conditions can be combined with and/or.
Filtering happens before the expression is applied.
concepts.example_hint: Filter even numbers from a list.

concepts.title: Nested Comprehensions
bullets: Comprehensions can iterate over multiple sequences.
Outer loop comes first, inner loop follows.
Useful for flattening nested lists.
Can also create matrices or grids.
Readability decreases with nesting depth.
concepts.example_hint: Flatten a 2D list into a 1D list.

concepts.title: When to Avoid
bullets: Avoid when logic is complex or has side effects.
Prefer loops when debugging is needed.
Long comprehensions hurt readability.
Generator expressions are better for large data.
Not suitable when you need early termination.
